content:
"""Documentation for Moving Window Aggregated Timeseries Plot

# Moving Window Aggregated Timeseries Plot

## Description
This component plots a time window based aggregated timeseries, e.g. based on mean or median, and the original timeseries.

## Inputs
* **original_timeseries** (Pandas Series): Series to perform the moving mean calculation on.
* **aggregated_timeseries** (Pandas Series): Series to perform the moving mean calculation on.
* **window_size** (String): Time span of each window. Can be either a pandas frequency string based on [date offset aliases](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/timeseries.html#timeseries-offset-aliases) or a timedelta string.
* **interval_type** (String): The string must be one of "left_closed", "right_open", "right_closed", "left_open", "closed", or "open". In case a datapoint is on the left or right border of a window, this option determines if it belongs to that window or not, but potentially a neighbouring window.
* **label_position** (String): The string must be either "left", "center", or "right". This option determines which timestamp is provided to represent the window for the corresponding mean in the output time series.
* **plotting_mode** (String): The string must be either "lines" or "dots_and_windows". This option specifies how the data and aggregate timeseries are visualized

## Outputs
* **plot** (Plotly JSON): The generated Plotly JSON. This is used by the hetida designer frontend for plotting the results.

## Details
The **window_size**, **closed**, and **label_position** parameters should be the same as those used to calculate the **aggregated_timeseries** based on the **original_timeseries**. These may not have been explicitly specified, so it may be necessary to look up the default values for the method used.

If the **plotting_mode** is set to 'lines' the window mean values as well as the datapoints are displayed as lines or if it is set to 'dots_and_windows' they are displayed by individual markers together with the windows for which the mean values have been calculated. In that case:
* The **window_size** is indicated by plotting lines of the corresponding horizontal length at the position of each aggregation value.
* The **interval_type** specifies which sides of the windows are closed, which is indicated by horizontal triangles at the edges of this line, pointing inward.
* A dot indicates the position of the timestamp along the line corresponding to the aggregation value corresponding to **label_position**. Technically, the line is placed relative to the dot according to this information, which can be important when looking for reasons for unexpected results.
* A dot indicates the position of the timestamp along the line corresponding to the aggregation value of **label_position**. Technically, the line is placed relative to the point according to this information, which can be important when looking for reasons for unexpected results.

If NaN values are present in the **aggregated_timeseries**, these will be dropped before plotting.


## Examples
The json input of a typical call of this component is
```
{
    "original_timeseries": {
        "2022-12-06 23:17:14+00:00": 14.360453,
        "2022-12-06 23:18:14+00:00": 14.872439,
        "2022-12-06 23:19:14+00:00": 15.803046,
        "2022-12-06 23:20:14+00:00": 13.661063,
        "2022-12-06 23:21:14+00:00": 14.969653,
        "2022-12-06 23:22:14+00:00": 13.530460,
        "2022-12-06 23:23:14+00:00": 14.009814,
        "2022-12-06 23:24:14+00:00": 13.708907,
        "2022-12-06 23:25:14+00:00": 15.119281,
        "2022-12-06 23:26:14+00:00": 15.666053,
        "2022-12-06 23:27:14+00:00": 15.488811,
        "2022-12-06 23:28:14+00:00": 15.515572,
        "2022-12-06 23:29:14+00:00": 14.767891,
        "2022-12-06 23:30:14+00:00": 13.726783,
        "2022-12-06 23:31:14+00:00": 14.997352,
        "2022-12-06 23:32:14+00:00": 13.015161,
        "2022-12-06 23:33:14+00:00": 15.079884,
        "2022-12-06 23:34:14+00:00": 15.001638,
        "2022-12-06 23:35:14+00:00": 16.035476,
        "2022-12-06 23:36:14+00:00": 14.545874,
        "2022-12-06 23:37:14+00:00": 13.970260,
        "2022-12-06 23:38:14+00:00": 15.045999,
        "2022-12-06 23:39:14+00:00": 13.824304,
        "2022-12-06 23:40:14+00:00": 13.620449,
        "2022-12-06 23:41:14+00:00": 15.146005,
        "2022-12-06 23:42:14+00:00": 14.796941,
        "2022-12-06 23:43:14+00:00": 17.036046,
        "2022-12-06 23:44:14+00:00": 14.976151,
        "2022-12-06 23:45:14+00:00": 14.637615,
        "2022-12-06 23:46:14+00:00": 15.195011,
        "2022-12-06 23:47:14+00:00": 14.082022,
        "2022-12-06 23:48:14+00:00": 15.311653,
        "2022-12-06 23:49:14+00:00": 15.534084,
        "2022-12-06 23:50:14+00:00": 15.020099,
        "2022-12-06 23:51:14+00:00": 14.020416,
        "2022-12-06 23:52:14+00:00": 13.779699,
        "2022-12-06 23:53:14+00:00": 14.407253,
        "2022-12-06 23:54:14+00:00": 15.180839,
        "2022-12-06 23:55:14+00:00": 14.618573,
        "2022-12-06 23:56:14+00:00": 14.194774,
        "2022-12-06 23:57:14+00:00": 14.653221,
        "2022-12-06 23:58:14+00:00": 14.911146,
        "2022-12-06 23:59:14+00:00": 14.951289,
        "2022-12-07 00:00:14+00:00": 15.005731,
        "2022-12-07 00:01:14+00:00": 15.708401,
        "2022-12-07 00:02:14+00:00": 13.605439,
        "2022-12-07 00:03:14+00:00": 14.620927,
        "2022-12-07 00:04:14+00:00": 15.181250,
        "2022-12-07 00:05:14+00:00": 13.912724,
        "2022-12-07 00:06:14+00:00": 14.060204
    },
    aggregated_timeseries": {
        "2022-12-06T23:22:30.000Z":14.5261166667,
        "2022-12-06T23:37:30.000Z":15.3292983333,
        "2022-12-06T23:52:30.000Z":13.96039,
        "2022-12-07T00:07:30.000Z":14.91716,
        "2022-12-07T00:22:30.000Z":14.2458843333,
        "2022-12-07T00:37:30.000Z":15.0975393333,
        "2022-12-07T00:52:30.000Z":14.9696723333,
        "2022-12-07T01:07:30.000Z":14.636221,
        "2022-12-07T01:22:30.000Z":13.2423086667,
        "2022-12-07T01:37:30.000Z":14.0745546667,
        "2022-12-07T01:52:30.000Z":14.487968,
        "2022-12-07T02:07:30.000Z":15.2930623333,
        "2022-12-07T02:22:30.000Z":14.722309,
        "2022-12-07T02:37:30.000Z":14.6024093333,
        "2022-12-07T02:52:30.000Z":14.740198,
        "2022-12-07T03:07:30.000Z":13.832052,
        "2022-12-07T03:22:30.000Z":14.4311765
    },
    "window_size": "15min",
    "interval_type": "left_closed",
    "label_position": "center",
    "plotting_mode": "dots_and_windows"
}
```
"""

from typing import Literal

import pandas as pd
import plotly.graph_objects as go
import plotly.io as pio
from pandas.tseries.frequencies import to_offset

from hdutils import plotly_fig_to_json_dict


def freqstr2timedelta(freqstr: str) -> pd.Timedelta:
    """Transform frequency string to Pandas Timedelta."""
    try:
        return pd.to_timedelta(freqstr)
    except ValueError:
        return pd.to_timedelta(to_offset(freqstr))


pio.templates.default = None


def timeseries_and_aggregate_plot(
    original_timeseries: pd.Series,
    aggregated_timeseries: pd.Series,
    window_size: pd.Timedelta,
    interval_type: Literal[
        "left_closed", "right_open", "right_closed", "left_open", "closed", "open"
    ],
    label_position: str,
    plotting_mode: Literal["lines", "dots_and_windows"] = "dots_and_windows",
    layout_opts: dict = {
        "xaxis_title": "Time",
        "yaxis_title": "Values",
        "autosize": True,
        "height": 200,
    },
) -> go.Figure:
    fig = go.Figure()

    marker_size = 6
    data_color = "gray"
    aggr_color = "mediumvioletred"
    line_width = 2

    aggregated_timeseries_for_plotting = aggregated_timeseries.dropna()

    # Add markers for data timeseries.
    fig.add_trace(
        go.Scatter(
            x=original_timeseries.index,
            y=original_timeseries.values,
            **(
                {"mode": "markers", "marker": dict(color=data_color)}
                if plotting_mode == "dots_and_windows"
                else {"mode": "lines", "line_color": data_color}
            ),
            name="original timeseries",
        ),
    )

    # Add markers for the aggregate timeseries.
    fig.add_trace(
        go.Scatter(
            x=aggregated_timeseries_for_plotting.index,
            y=aggregated_timeseries_for_plotting.values,
            **(
                {"mode": "markers", "marker": dict(size=marker_size, color=aggr_color)}
                if plotting_mode == "dots_and_windows"
                else {"mode": "lines", "line_color": aggr_color}
            ),
            name="aggregated timeseries",
        ),
    )

    if plotting_mode == "dots_and_windows":
        # Determine start and end point positions relative to the label positions.
        x0_offset = pd.Timedelta(0)
        x1_offset = pd.Timedelta(0)
        if label_position == "left":
            x1_offset = window_size
        elif label_position == "right":
            x0_offset = window_size
        else:  # label_position == "center"
            x0_offset = window_size / 2
            x1_offset = window_size / 2

        # Add markers to show if the left side of the window is closed
        if interval_type in ["left_closed", "right_open", "closed"]:
            fig.add_trace(
                go.Scatter(
                    x=aggregated_timeseries_for_plotting.index - x0_offset,
                    y=aggregated_timeseries_for_plotting.values,
                    mode="markers",
                    marker=dict(
                        size=marker_size + 2,
                        color=aggr_color,
                        symbol=8,
                    ),
                    name="left closed",
                ),
            )

        # Add markers to show if the right side of the window is closed
        if interval_type in ["right_closed", "left_open", "closed"]:
            fig.add_trace(
                go.Scatter(
                    x=aggregated_timeseries_for_plotting.index + x1_offset,
                    y=aggregated_timeseries_for_plotting.values,
                    mode="markers",
                    marker=dict(
                        size=marker_size + 2,
                        color=aggr_color,
                        symbol=7,
                    ),
                    name="right closed",
                ),
            )

        # Add lines for each window indicating the window size
        for index, value in aggregated_timeseries_for_plotting.items():
            fig.add_shape(
                type="line",
                x0=index - x0_offset,
                x1=index + x1_offset,
                y0=value,
                y1=value,
                line=dict(color=aggr_color, width=line_width),
                name="window size",
            )

    # Set the layout.
    fig.update_layout(**layout_opts)

    # Set margins.
    fig.update_layout(margin=dict(l=0, r=0, b=0, t=5, pad=0))
    fig.update_yaxes(automargin=True)
    fig.update_xaxes(automargin=True)

    return fig


# # ***** DO NOT EDIT LINES BELOW *****
# These lines may be overwritten if component details or inputs/outputs change.
COMPONENT_INFO = {
    "inputs": {
        "original_timeseries": {"data_type": "SERIES"},
        "aggregated_timeseries": {"data_type": "SERIES"},
        "window_size": {"data_type": "STRING"},
        "interval_type": {"data_type": "STRING"},
        "label_position": {"data_type": "STRING"},
        "plotting_mode": {"data_type": "STRING"},
    },
    "outputs": {
        "plot": {"data_type": "PLOTLYJSON"},
    },
    "name": "Moving Window Aggregated Timeseries Plot",
    "category": "Visualization",
    "description": "Plot a time window based aggregated timeseries and the original timeseries",
    "version_tag": "1.0.0",
    "id": "eb46db4e-aab5-4f93-8330-9423f0a2a34a",
    "revision_group_id": "f8c5e505-bb87-4814-bf77-6ce1698851ff",
    "state": "RELEASED",
    "released_timestamp": "2022-11-24T13:30:23.468744+00:00",
}

from hdutils import parse_default_value  # noqa: E402, F401


def main(
    *,
    original_timeseries,
    aggregated_timeseries,
    window_size,
    interval_type,
    label_position,
    plotting_mode,
):
    # entrypoint function for this component
    # ***** DO NOT EDIT LINES ABOVE *****
    # write your function code here.
    return {
        "plot": plotly_fig_to_json_dict(
            timeseries_and_aggregate_plot(
                original_timeseries=original_timeseries,
                aggregated_timeseries=aggregated_timeseries,
                window_size=freqstr2timedelta(window_size),
                interval_type=interval_type,
                label_position=label_position,
                plotting_mode=plotting_mode,
            )
        )
    }

                "value": '{\n    "2022-12-06T23:22:30.000Z": 14.5261166667,\n    "2022-12-06T23:37:30.000Z": 15.3292983333,\n    "2022-12-06T23:52:30.000Z": 13.96039,\n    "2022-12-07T00:07:30.000Z": 14.91716,\n    "2022-12-07T00:22:30.000Z": 14.2458843333,\n    "2022-12-07T00:37:30.000Z": 15.0975393333,\n    "2022-12-07T00:52:30.000Z": 14.9696723333,\n    "2022-12-07T01:07:30.000Z": 14.636221,\n    "2022-12-07T01:22:30.000Z": 13.2423086667,\n    "2022-12-07T01:37:30.000Z": 14.0745546667,\n    "2022-12-07T01:52:30.000Z": 14.487968,\n    "2022-12-07T02:07:30.000Z": 15.2930623333,\n    "2022-12-07T02:22:30.000Z": 14.722309,\n    "2022-12-07T02:37:30.000Z": 14.6024093333,\n    "2022-12-07T02:52:30.000Z": 14.740198,\n    "2022-12-07T03:07:30.000Z": 13.832052,\n    "2022-12-07T03:22:30.000Z": 14.4311765\n}'
            },
        },
        {"workflow_input_name": "window_size", "filters": {"value": "15min"}},

description: Plot a time window based aggregated timeseries and the original timeseries
documentation:
# Moving Window Aggregated Timeseries Plot

## Description
This component plots a time window based aggregated timeseries, e.g. based on mean or median, and the original timeseries.

## Inputs
* **original_timeseries** (Pandas Series): Series to perform the moving mean calculation on.
* **aggregated_timeseries** (Pandas Series): Series to perform the moving mean calculation on.
* **window_size** (String): Time span of each window. Can be either a pandas frequency string based on [date offset aliases](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/timeseries.html#timeseries-offset-aliases) or a timedelta string.
* **interval_type** (String): The string must be one of "left_closed", "right_open", "right_closed", "left_open", "closed", or "open". In case a datapoint is on the left or right border of a window, this option determines if it belongs to that window or not, but potentially a neighbouring window.
* **label_position** (String): The string must be either "left", "center", or "right". This option determines which timestamp is provided to represent the window for the corresponding mean in the output time series.
* **plotting_mode** (String): The string must be either "lines" or "dots_and_windows". This option specifies how the data and aggregate timeseries are visualized

## Outputs
* **plot** (Plotly JSON): The generated Plotly JSON. This is used by the hetida designer frontend for plotting the results.

## Details
The **window_size**, **closed**, and **label_position** parameters should be the same as those used to calculate the **aggregated_timeseries** based on the **original_timeseries**. These may not have been explicitly specified, so it may be necessary to look up the default values for the method used.

If the **plotting_mode** is set to 'lines' the window mean values as well as the datapoints are displayed as lines or if it is set to 'dots_and_windows' they are displayed by individual markers together with the windows for which the mean values have been calculated. In that case:
* The **window_size** is indicated by plotting lines of the corresponding horizontal length at the position of each aggregation value.
* The **interval_type** specifies which sides of the windows are closed, which is indicated by horizontal triangles at the edges of this line, pointing inward.
* A dot indicates the position of the timestamp along the line corresponding to the aggregation value corresponding to **label_position**. Technically, the line is placed relative to the dot according to this information, which can be important when looking for reasons for unexpected results.
* A dot indicates the position of the timestamp along the line corresponding to the aggregation value of **label_position**. Technically, the line is placed relative to the point according to this information, which can be important when looking for reasons for unexpected results.

If NaN values are present in the **aggregated_timeseries**, these will be dropped before plotting.


## Examples
The json input of a typical call of this component is
```
{
    "original_timeseries": {
        "2022-12-06 23:17:14+00:00": 14.360453,
        "2022-12-06 23:18:14+00:00": 14.872439,
        "2022-12-06 23:19:14+00:00": 15.803046,
        "2022-12-06 23:20:14+00:00": 13.661063,
        "2022-12-06 23:21:14+00:00": 14.969653,
        "2022-12-06 23:22:14+00:00": 13.530460,
        "2022-12-06 23:23:14+00:00": 14.009814,
        "2022-12-06 23:24:14+00:00": 13.708907,
        "2022-12-06 23:25:14+00:00": 15.119281,
        "2022-12-06 23:26:14+00:00": 15.666053,
        "2022-12-06 23:27:14+00:00": 15.488811,
        "2022-12-06 23:28:14+00:00": 15.515572,
        "2022-12-06 23:29:14+00:00": 14.767891,
        "2022-12-06 23:30:14+00:00": 13.726783,
        "2022-12-06 23:31:14+00:00": 14.997352,
        "2022-12-06 23:32:14+00:00": 13.015161,
        "2022-12-06 23:33:14+00:00": 15.079884,
        "2022-12-06 23:34:14+00:00": 15.001638,
        "2022-12-06 23:35:14+00:00": 16.035476,
        "2022-12-06 23:36:14+00:00": 14.545874,
        "2022-12-06 23:37:14+00:00": 13.970260,
        "2022-12-06 23:38:14+00:00": 15.045999,
        "2022-12-06 23:39:14+00:00": 13.824304,
        "2022-12-06 23:40:14+00:00": 13.620449,
        "2022-12-06 23:41:14+00:00": 15.146005,
        "2022-12-06 23:42:14+00:00": 14.796941,
```

name: Moving Window Aggregated Timeseries Plot
